I've been on like a decade long search to find a game that could scratch my classic Zoo Tycoon itch. I wanted a simple city builder that wasn't just buildings. I wanted interactions with characters, challenges, and the option to play "freestyle" without worrying about time passing or funds. This game satisfies my Zoo Tycoon needs. 

Cute character designs and city details. Chill music, nothing too distracting or anxiety-inducing - option to turn the music down, and I'm guessing off completely but I haven't tried. Two options to play with limitations (ex: starting with low funds) or play "creatively" where you have limitless resources. Easy controls, easy build options, quick tutorial... Love the objectives - constant flow of new challenges, messages, announcements, etc. to take on with the option to dismiss or delay the challenge. Lots of flexibility so you can play the game how YOU want to play, even if you select the standard play option.

I was worried it would be a farming sim - although there is farming, it's not the highlight and you don't have to physically move the character and press A or B a million times to uproot carrots. It does it automatically when you assign a worker to the farm, so you get the taste of farming without any of the repetitive actions I've come to dislike so much in the wave of farming sims that have flooded the gaming world. 

I don't have a good gaming computer, so my only complaint so far is self-inflicted: the graphics are too much for my computer, so it runs a little slow on startup and when autosaving. Turning the graphics option to "medium" instead of "ultra" helped. I'm sure turning the wind off would help too, but it's too cute to disable. 

Anyway, absolutely recommend.

TLDR; Dont, has basic issues, crashes on ultra settings (has since launch) and while shows great progress, and will probably be a great game. Not yet. 

I really wanted to love this game.. The magical creatures showcased, the fun chill management, and i loved seeing the progress they were posting in their logs- and now, after having "totally legally" tried it when it first came out, and whilst it was very flawed, i saw they had updated it a lot and i decided, now its time to give it a go! Bought it, now im refunding.. It has fundamental flaws, and ones unfixed - it isnt worth your time or money yet, if you are already on the fence about it.

So first of all i found out, after only 15 min that apparently when i used winkey+prntscr for a screenshot of some funny text, that the game would hang (this isnt reliable, i couldnt replicate?) despite running smoothly, and then crash, and it took me another 10 min, trying to reload back into my auto save to get back, it would crash repeatedly, and then finally for no reason would let me back in - there was also some graphical glitches associated with it, like the ground texture being completely black. I eventually figured out that the ultra settings (im on a beefy system and it ran highest with very high fps) somehow the game would bug out graphically or crash. So was forced to play on medium settings..

As for the actual gameplay itself, it has a cute gameplay loop and a lot of neat and fun ideas but it suffers from a few things - for a relatively chill looking casual game, it actually manages to put you in a perpetual under-powered state, leaving you constantly feeling struggles once you reach the "second act" or whatever you wanna call it. And it becomes kind of a dull repeated struggle, and limits your progression, it sort of went from "oh look we're having fun, and chilling" to banished like management of "your people are dying every winter!" and the fundamental issues in design really showed their face here, you get too little people, to manage your buildings, even when played perfectly & with prior knowledge. 

The problem isnt so much the difficulty though as it is that, it doesnt feel satisfying, being left with excess nothing, feeling like you didnt really progress. And meeting the "noble goals" is almost entirely imbalanced early game, being if your goal structure isnt already built (like if your goal is to catch fish, and you have just placed the building to be constructed, which happens often because you are progressing in the game and they pop up as you unlock them) theres 0 chance you can manage in time. It was kind of 50/50 if the goal was achievable or not. Again i think this game is suffering from a crisis of "am i a hard game, or a relaxed cute looking game" and being left in a position that constantly doesnt feel like "i could have done better with this" but instead "well this is just unfair and unreasonable with what i was able to do with the population i been given" 

And some other minor gripes, is that - theres no variation besides "skin color" in the people you get, everyone just looks like the same fat eggman dude or the same eggman looking woman, with only slight difference.. And they dont actually seem to have any level of life or soul in them, you cant really follow them around and name them and care about them, well.. you can if you try and make up your own story in your mind, but it doesnt come to play in game, which i feel is a lost opportunity, in many other management games, you have someone that you know what they do "oh john/jane doe here is a farmer, and he's been struggling with their tasks and making due and likes to go to the bar in the evening" or whatever, you end up with "another mindless eggman drone" - and i genuinely thought and hoped that this game would bring more life into the mix. And if you enter it thinking or hoping it will, you're be a bit let down im afraid

The Encounters are interesting and i love a lot of the mechanics, however, they also suffer a bit from "i dont know what i want to be as a game" be it hard, or relaxed, indept and following your "heroes" or just a "this is military unit #7" I think the game needs more identity and love in terms of "the people and personalities" and very much needs to ease up on the gas, or at least go harder and deeper on the petal. This in between life doesnt mesh well and isnt working out as a pleasant experience. 

I hope this has helped you. Ill leave some design suggestions
- allow trading earlier and easier, so you can exchange resources 
- give more people, or increase effective output 
- give people more life and interaction, talking & going to have a meal or a drink, relationships!
- give people variation and not just eggman#32... If they MUST have THE SAME body and face, at least give them hats/clothes? But id much rather be able to identify them. Make them people
- when played "optimally" the game doesnt feel like you have much choice, id like to VIABLY be able to have more options.. Or focusing on a specific type of field like "this village is focusing on stonework and imports more food" or vice versa. The game feels too.. "closed loop"

Good luck, and have a pleasant day.

149007132.review:
Strongly recommend trying this game out! If you're a fan of light, simple city-builder type games, then you'll feel right at home with this one. I've been following this one since its early days on Twitter. It's had a LOT of polishing up and feels very well put together, and the dev team is fantastic and very receptive to its fanbase!

GAMEPLAY: ★★★★
Almost perfect, for what this is! It's your typical square-grid builder type interface. UI feels good, it's simple and to the point. Placing buildings isn't terribly finicky, and has improved a fair bit since the game's initial EA started. But there's more to it than placing buildings and making your citizens happy by giving them access to resources. On the side, you can direct a hero to interact with event items scattered throughout your area. Often, this yields rewards. In the future, heroes will have a much greater role in terms of gameplay. Lots of potential that's actively getting realized, bit by bit!

GRAPHICS: ★★★★★
Fantastic stuff! It's very cute and stylized, has a low impact footprint on systems, and does a very decent job giving off that cartoony fantasy vibe. The shaders and particle effects integrated in the environments are very well done and textures blend seamlessly in with each other in a very organic fashion. I'm excited to see what other visuals we'll get as the game grows.

SOUND: ★★★★
Music is nice and fits the vibe well, changing dynamically with events as they come, they did a decent job keeping the feel of a fantasy hamlet without going crazy on the brass and string section like you find in so many other games to feel "epic". Maybe that's a personal taste of mine, but I like that the music is a little more understated and subdued to feel relaxing and immersive. The sounds of the villagers, buildings, and environment ambiance is also very well done. Nothing's loud or too plosive on the ears.

STORY: ★★★
Okay, so there's not much to tell, but it is pretty charming at premise! You take on the role of a lord, new to the region, and start off building a settlement for your little villagers. Shortly thereafter, you'll begin to integrate in the community of other local empires as a new neighbor, while seeking out a cute, romantic bond with one of the regional lords and ladies! Along the way, you'll solve dilemmas for your people and send your hero out to investigate mysterious events in the realm. Right now, it's pretty simple for what it is, but the devs have much more in mind for this game as it grows. The game's trying to tell a story with you at the helm, after all.

ACCESSIBILITY: ★★★★
As this is an early access game, there's still a lot to improve upon and give us as users. Right now, unfortunately, there isn't a ton in the way of accessibility features. But the devs are listening in discussions and are eager to jot down and use feedback to improve the game. No colorblind support as of yet, but the game does allow for personalized controls. Newbie experience with the game makes learning how to play as a first-timer to city builders a breeze, and you can disable such tutorials if you're already practiced at it. And the UI's got a fair number of languages supported! (English, traditional Chinese, simplified Chinese, French, German, Russian, Spanish, and Portuguese) More can be added as time goes on and development focuses on these QoL additions.

OVERALL: ★★★★
Definitely worth picking up and trying! It feels great to play and it'll only get better with time and more feedback from the community! This is a much smaller dev team and they're very eager to make this game go far.

143049830.review:
Fabledom is a nice, relaxing city/kingdom builder for more chill gaming sessions. It's easy to learn and understand, and not too complicated for people who tend to get overwhelmed by the management features in other games of its kind. Unlike other games of the same genre that only have one speed setting, Fabledom allows you to speed up time in order for the Fablings to walk and work faster (similar to the functionality in the Sims). This is definitely not the kind of game to speedrun or grind for more serious players who enjoy other city expansion games like Cities: Skylines and SimCity.

There are a few features of the game that could use some tweaking and adjusting, such as the ability to prioritize the construction of different buildings. Whenever I have had this box checked, it does not seem to make the Fablings "prioritize" the selected structure, and they continue to distribute resources to other buildings instead. I also read a review mentioning the capability to decline courting other rulers. While I do enjoy the feature of discovering your own "happily ever after", I agree that there should be an option to simply remain friends with the leaders of surrounding realms. Finally, there seems to be a lack of efficiency with resources being moved from one place to another, as I have found my Fablings sitting around with "nothing" to do, despite there being ongoing construction and expansion.

Regardless, the design and roleplay aspect of the game is a cute and fun integration for a city builder, making it a simple yet entertaining game to play when you have a few hours to spare. If you're interested in this game, I would wait for it to go on sale, or for more updates to be released to justify the listed price, as it is quite high for an early access game. I believe there is plenty to do between updates, and a lot of fun to be had. This fantasy-esque city builder is straightforward and quite easily addicting, and I highly recommend it.

142375967.review:
Very nice game - definitely looking forward to when it has been built out more. Currently it is very bare bones and not much here for more than 8 hours of play and little incentive for replayability. 

There's a bunch of opportunities for this game to make the game feel better.
1. Needs to be a clearer explanation of where income comes from - if it is only from the citizens then I believe we should be able to generate gold from buildings, or depending on the quality of worker (peasant vs commoner) we should be able to generate resources faster - so we can trade (sell) to other kingdoms for gold. 

2. We need to be able to relocate people to different houses.  I have 2 areas in my city for housing vs workplaces. I would like to make sure my people work closer to home so I can manage happiness. But population automatically fills older built houses instead of houses closer to workplaces. I should be able to relocate people so I can move them to houses closer to workplaces I need to fill. 

3. Stockpiles - it would be great if stockpile employees worked to distribute resources amongst other stockpiles - so that we we don't end up with 1 stockpile on 1 end of the map with all the coal - for example.

4. Labourers Hut - more than 1 labourer should work on a building at a time. If there is only 1 building being built, all labourers should be working on it - not 1 working and the others sitting around. If there's multiple buildings, then a fair distribution of labourers if fine. However, if a building is prioritised then all labourers should focus on it. 

5. Buildings should be able to be rotated once built. It's a small QOL thing but it would help. Condomoniums are the worst for this. If the townhouses have a door facing another building or a wall then people can't access it and get stuck all the time. 

6. At around 100 pop gold generation is too slow (if you've kept up with jobs and everyone is employed). It takes 10 minutes to save gold to do 1 action, then you just wait around. Very disengaging part of the game. 

7. Walls don't seem practical. Given cities are built in a sprawl and extended out based on tiles purchased, I don't understand how walls would be an appealing aesthetically as they would be going everywhere. 

8. Pathways should have an upgrade option. If I want to upgrade my dirt road to cobblestone I should be able to just select and upgrade, or have an upgrade tool similar to the destruction tool. Also upgrading should be discounted (eg. dirt to cobblestone would cost 3 instead of 5)

9. I'm sure this is planned for when the fishing hut becomes available - but fish tiles in the water should actually show fish (think Age of Empires)

10. Finally we should be able to place buildings down even if we don't have the resources for them (but not able to click build) so we can do "town planning" with the buildings' outlines.  

Overall I think this city builder has a lot of potential, the devs just need more time to put more meat on the bones. 
Excited to see where it goes.

141396228.review:
In a few words: Charming, but not without issues.

Having only played up to town houses, my partial impression is that the primary game play loop is healthy, if a bit basic. There are not too many resources to manage right away, and the production chains are very simple. 

New citizens trickle in slowly and the margins on production per worker feel fairly thin, I don't think I've ever felt like I had an overflowing stockpile of anything most of the time. While this does feel fairly balanced it I also felt like I didn't have much agency in selecting what resources to pursue, every new citizen already had their job decided the moment they arrived since allocating them to any other resource would quickly guarantee a shortage.

I don't think the margins being thin would bother me as much if it wasn't also necessary for me to manually assign them to the specific job sites. This problem becomes particularly egregious in winter when farming tasks can no longer be completed, but the citizens stand around at their assigned farming job sites anyway requiring a tedious UI dance each year to temporarily reassign them one-by-one to other work.

I haven't touched much of the systems related to diplomacy or martial stuff, if there's much to be said for it then it's not apparent during the early-mid phases of the game, if the structure/development tiers are a reliable read on it.

On a few positive notes, the overall design is endearing and the artwork and little cartoony details are cute and fulfill the fairy tale theme nicely. The interface does a serviceable job and tells you most of what you want to know in an intuitive way.

As a platform for future development, I think it has excellent potential, even if it's excusably rough in some spots at the moment.

141246239.review:
I have to start by saying that this game is almost uncomfortably similar to Foundation in aesthetic and mechanics. Many of its features, like expansion into adjacent areas through purchase and modular buildings, have appeared in other games and proven to be deep and interesting mechanics that are worth reusing, but this specific combination of them with this specific presentation left a bad taste in my mouth. I wouldn't normally put a lot of stock into this sort of thing, because city builders can only have so much deviation, but even really basic stuff like the design and layout of the UI, down to the color and shape of the dropdown boxes, are eerily similar. I'm not necessarily opposed to looking at an interesting idea and making some tweaks, but you have to actually do it better to be successful.
Unfortunately, a major part of this game's similarity- deliberate or otherwise- is every new world starting with a mandatory quest-based guided experience that locks off buildings until the tutorial is ready for you to place them, hand-feeding you rewards to compensate for the fact that you have no control over your own income for the first hour or two. Even if I set aside the fact that I feel like I've done this before, I have to do it on the pretense that most city builders necessarily follow a similar formula, so locking off obvious inclusions like farms and woodcutters until I'm ready to handle them feels like a waste of my time.
The places where this game does innovate are arguably marks against it, because the two immediately obvious from the first minute are a grating narrator you can't opt out of and the predefined goal of finding a romantic partner. I could just turn the voice volume down, but honestly, the urge to turn off the narrator is more an urge to have control over what I'm doing. The storybook presentation, framed as a flashback retold from after the end of the game, highlights that my goals are pre-defined- and that I've done this all before. I understand the drive to present a more narrative-driven take on city builders, and assuredly there is a point where the game opens up and gives the player more to work with, but so much about this game conspires to highlight that lack of input.
Maybe my gripes are personal ones, and other players can look past them. For me, this formula just isn't what I come to city builders for- and even if it was, I've gotten it better elsewhere.

Fabledom is as relaxing as it can be, while still having all the mechanics you would expect from a city builder. The graphics, the music, the whole premise of the game make it a truly joyful experience. 
The idea of being able to befriend, court and then presumably marry one of the other rulers - while also being able to befriend and/or antagonize and go to war with the others - is a new concept for the genre, but a really welcome one.

I'm mighty curious to see what will happen if you end up marrying one of the other rulers: will the kingdoms be united under one banner? Will they be permanently locked into an alliance? And how will the other rulers respond to the union? I can't wait to find out.

TL;DR: if you want a city builder that is as relaxing as it is cute, with good graphics and an even better music score, then Fabledom is for you. The sandbox mode is perfect for those that wants to focus on building their city without worrying about unlocking buildings and managing resources, while the campaign mode lets you experience a more traditional city building trajectory, so to speak.

CORRECTO

No es ni mucho menos el mejor juego de gestión de recursos, pero tampoco es malo. Con una estética más que cuidada y "cute", Fabledom nos acerca a un mundo fantástico-medieval con una historia de trasfondo divertida. 

El comienzo del juego es muy chulo, con un estupendo acabado y un bonito doblaje que te mete de lleno en el mundo. Empiezas con un tutorial la mar de sencillo, que te permite ir jugando y avanzando mientras aprendes. Desde luego, muy correcto. 
El problema empieza cuando llevas bastante tiempo de partida, aproximadamente a las dos horas. Supongo que es porque aún está en "early access", pero me ha costado mucho avanzar. Durante casi una hora he estado mirando la pantalla esperando subir número de aldeanos. No dejaba de construir granjas, graneros, panaderías... Y aun así, los aldeanos se morían de hambruna. Al tiempo "intuí" que se debía a los largos caminos que hacían los aldeanos hasta sus trabajos, asi que reorganicé por completo el sistema de trabajo, y en cuestión de otros veinte minutos conseguí remontar la situación. 
De igual manera, y aunque esto me ha supuesto perder una gran parte del tiempo, es un buen producto. El juego está bien hecho, no destaca por sus mecánicas ni por su temática, vista en cientos de juegos de gestión de recursos, pero me da la sensación de que aún me queda mucho por descubrir del fantástico mundo de FABLEDOM. 
Me quedaré a la espera de los avances, y a los devs, les deseo lo mejor con este título, que estoy segura de que llegará a funcionar muy bien entre los fans del género.

So far there's about 8 hours of gameplay in here. It says I've played it for 8.7, but the .7 of an hour was easily the first time I played where the game loaded me onto a map with no trees or rocks. Rather than realizing this could be problematic, my newbie self thought, "maybe fog of war?" Not the case. Moving on.

I got this game because I wanted a city builder with a fantasy aspect. I was really hoping for wizards, magic, unicorns, the works - but in my own little fantasy city. The most I saw was that the pigs have wings, otherwise everything else is just medieval. They promised more to come, so maybe the fabled magic is there in the future. 

There are tiers of building - but not to indicate your status as an evolving builder. The lowest tier building must continually be built to support peasants, the higher tier building (the one I had access to) gave me a different sort of citizen that had limited use. Honestly I wasn't sure why I had to upgrade to the second tier building, as this was neither useful for supporting my mini economy (commoners can only do limited jobs), nor easy to get. I suppose the sense of accomplishment was pretty much it. 

Speaking of economy, it's very simple. You have X houses that support Y peasants, and you need so many farms to support the peasants, who work the farms. So on. That's the challenging balance so far - getting the stone masons and flour mills to support your little people - who you need to work these things, thus growth. Beyond that, I didn't have access to other economy tools. Adjusting taxation was going to be available at a later date (or so the screen said), but I was really hoping for a little council system or politics or something once I got high enough tiered. I also wanted to see my buildings change look as I advanced to indicate my progress (from clay walls to brick and so on).

For building space and such I did feel pushed to expand my territory at appropriate times. I'd get squished and either have the money to expand or realize the need to save a little to get it done. This aspect felt balanced. I liked the idea that some buildings made homeowners unhappy, while some made them happier. This was a fun challenge - I just wish I could see them go in the buildings and come out with smiles or something. That would have been rewarding.

I also liked the music. It was calming and chill, exactly what I wanted for my Covid brain to zone out on. The graphics, while simple, are colorful and lovely, and that appeals to me greatly. I found myself building away contentedly for quite a while before the game finally went, "well'p you're done for now. Thanks for playing early access." 

I know they have lots in store for this game (a good portion of options were greyed out), so I might come back when it's all done. I hope they don't make me pay more money because charging people to beta test a game is already not cool. Really hoping for more whimsy and personality once things get hammered out. Cheers.

138077101.review:
Érase una vez en un reino muy muy lejano… un maravilloso y relajante constructor de ciudades llamado Fabledom. Desarrollado por Grenaa Games y publicado por Dear Villagers llegó en acceso anticipado para PC a Steam el pasado 13 de abril de 2023 y la recepción ha sido realmente buena (89% de más de 1000 reseñas son positivas).

Como amante de los juegos de estrategia y la construcción de ciudades os puedo decir que es un juego que me llamó la atención por su estética y jugabilidad y que me provocó mucha curiosidad por saber si merecería la pena. Así que en estas líneas de abajo os cuento lo que he encontrado tras probar Fabledom en su etapa inicial de acceso anticipado.

[h1]Una historia de príncipes y princesas[/h1]

El bonito constructor de ciudades Fabledom se inicia con una historia muy sencilla, eres el príncipe o princesa y tomas el control de un reino, el cual podrás escoger entre 8 disponibles para hacerlo crecer y prosperar. En ti se encuentra la decisión de hacerlo con mano dura o con cariño y felicidad para tus fablings, mediante la diplomacia o la guerra (aún no está disponible) con los reinos vecinos.

Una vez que tomes el control de tu reino deberás gestionarlo desde cero en un mundo de fantasía con cerdos alados, árboles que hablan, héroes míticos que lucharán por ti, y varias misiones primarias y secundarias que te irán guiando mientras se suceden los capítulos de este cuento. El hecho de guiar la jugabilidad con una historia contada como un cuento es algo que me ha parecido original y que le da una buena base a la estrategia del título. Todo un acierto.

[h1]¿Qué encontramos en Fabledom?[/h1]

Entremos en harina (nunca mejor dicho) con las mecánicas de Fabledom. Este título de estrategia me ha recordado desde el primer momento a The Settlers, franquicia exitosa y de la que disfruté mucho, tanto en el aspecto de los personajes como en el sistema de gestión de recursos. Nuestro objetivo será alimentar a nuestros fablings (aldeanos), mantenerlos calientes, con agua, limpios,… vamos, cubrir sus necesidades más básicas y algo de ocio. Para ello tenemos que recoger y almacenar madera, piedra y metal y cosechar alimentos, crear carbón, fabricar pan,… lo típico. Es un sistema que no innova pero está muy bien implementado y es divertido.

Una de las mecánicas que le aportan diversión a Fabledom es el sistema de estaciones, y es que nuestro asentamiento irá pasando cada 30 días de estación. De la primavera al caluroso verano, luego al otoño y finalmente al temido invierno, época en que las cosechas se pararán y el frío asolará a tus aldeanos. Así que será importante que hagas acopio de víveres y carbón para hacer frente al crudo invierno o alguno de tus fablings puede llegar a morir. Además, existen eventos sorpresa como vecinos que te mandan regalos en caso de apuros o brujas que hechizan a tus aldeanos y que pueden arruinar tu planificación o salvar tu economía en un momento de apuro.

Con todo esto deberemos administrar nuestra economía a base de impuestos para poder ganar monedas con las que poder evolucionar nuestro asentamiento construyendo nuevos edificios de producción y ocio, y viviendas que nos permitirán aceptar nuevos colonos y aumentar la población y el rango de nuestro reino. Las monedas también nos servirán para ampliar el terreno y descubrir nuevos recursos o eventos.

El último punto a resaltar es el sistema de diplomacia con los dirigentes de otros reinos, con los cuales podremos contactar mediante un mensajero e ir mejorando la relación a través de misiones y regalos hasta incluso conquistar su corazón o llegar a las armas (esta parte aún no está disponible pero tiene buena pinta). De momento solo hay dos reinos disponibles pero llegarán más para llenar de contenido Fabledom un juego que sin estar completo me ha parecido muy divertido de jugar.

[h1]Una ambientación y temática que invita a la relajación y el disfrute[/h1]

Visualmente tiene un estilo que entra por los ojos, el diseño caricaturesco de los personajes, edificios y paisajes es entrañable y divertido, y te da sensación de paz y tranquilidad. Es muy bonito de ver, simplemente ver a los fablings trabajando con todo lujo de detalles denota el gran trabajo que hay detrás. Por otro lado, las texturas todavía se ven con margen de mejora, ya que parecen poco pulidas, pero no restan belleza al apartado gráfico.

Sonoramente quizás es la parte que más trabajo les quede, la música suena bien y va a la perfección con el juego, pero con las horas puede hacerse repetitiva. Un poco de variedad en este aspecto sumaría mucho a la experiencia.

[h1]Impresiones[/h1]

Quizás sea pronto para sacar conclusiones, pero tras probar Fabledom en fase de acceso anticipado y sabiendo que les queda mucho contenido por añadir, me atrevo a recomendarlo y deciros que lo tiene todo para ser un éxito para los amantes de la estrategia de construcción de ciudades.

Entre sus puntos más fuertes tenemos por un lado el estilo tipo cartoon de los diseños que es atractivo y va en consonancia con la ambientación relajada del juego, por otro lado la diversión basada en un buen diseño de la gestión de recursos y todas las mecánicas estratégicas originales como los romances y la diplomacia entre reinos, los eventos sorpresa,… y lo que está por venir. ¡Larga vida a Fabledom!

Apart from the necessity expansion of the content, the game features really good and cute graphics, a good variety of things to do in the game, some sort of a story, replayability and a very nice and relaxing soundtrack.

Overall, this is NOT your typical medieval city builder sim; the focus is more on diplomacy, courting a noble from another faction, interaction with the surroundings and generally having a good time.
I give it a thumbs-up and recommend the game if you're looking for a relaxing and simple building sim. I invested in the EA build and have not regrettet it since.

Fabledom was mentioned on social media, and I instantly thought this would be a game for me. So I set up a Steam account, learned the PC keys, and even learned to use Discord so I could see the progression of the game and join the community.

In short, I came for the flying piglets and stayed for Giovanni. 

Having only played a few games on console, I found it easy enough to navigate the game on PC. The tutorial is clear and not overbearing. There is so much to learn about the game, and 22 hours in, I am having so much fun! Yes, there are a few bugs at times in these early stages, but it is very clear that the developers are working hard to fix them all efficiently. At this stage, it took me a good 6 hours to finish the early access content, and then I started a new realm to practice all the things I had learned from my own mistakes and from other players' advice. Everything in game is absolutely adorable, there are so many cute details to look out for, I am loving the humour, and the music makes it all so relaxing and immersive. The game can be played from a bird's eye view to make it easier to organise everything, but I also love getting all zoomed in and even following my Fablings to see them waddle about their day. 

I am not sure how to describe the performance because I don't understand video games and PCs all that much. But I am happy. Using an RTX 2070 laptop with 8th gen i7, 16GB RAM (whatever that means).

I am beyond excited to see where the story goes: will I forever tie my realm to Giovanni's? Will Agnes steal my heart away? There will be love, maybe war, but mostly cosy farming and a gentle expansion of my little Fabling community.

PS. My boyfriend wants to thank the developers. Now that I am playing on PC, he can justify buying himself a new one so I can get his old one...

This is still in early access, and I will amend if need be, but right now this lands on my "must have" list of city building games. I've played through all the early access story content thus far and the creative mode content as well. Here's what I think so far:

Not only is this game SUPER cute, the artwork is really well done and the continuity in style as your city grows is great. I find that in some city builders that the jump from one type of smaller town to the upgraded bigger town buildings is sometimes jarring in style, and your city tends to look disjointed because of that. 

Every time you start a new story a new map seed is created, which keeps the orientation of the lands fresh and new for each playthrough. I love the layouts I've seen so far, but I do wish I could find a way to get up the hills with roads. Because of that I've strayed away from lands with too many of them. I'm not sure if that's a future feature or not, but it was a pain point for my first town as I had to build everything around them, and I found it a huge waste of space.

The UI is easy to navigate and pretty intuitive. It controls much like other city building games. I haven't had any issues so far with this at all.

The narrator is funny. You hear him mostly in the very beginning as you're first starting out, and less so as the game progresses, though he still pops up from time to time. I do appreciate that you're reminded he's still there without him chatting all the time as some games do. It keeps his witty comments fresh without wearing him out and making him annoying. I hope this continues into full release.

Also eager to see more world events than just the witch turning my villagers into skeletons (which, by the way, while super annoying and tears through my food stores, I love how the ambiance of the game changes and turns all spooky). 

Now, something I don't like - I'm not a fan of the merchant prince. And this is fine, as I'm pretty sure we'll be introduced to more than him and the harvest princess (who I do like). I just don't like his overall character and demeanor. 

I also wish my hero had a bit more to do, though I understand that there will be as time goes on. I just hate to see poor Fergus standing at a crossroads in my town in his little straw hat looking bored. I've sat him next to Bob Barkskin for the time being so he has someone to chat with. 

Other than that I've really enjoyed the small chunk of game that has been offered to us so far. I can't wait for it to grow so that I can wrangle up the sheep and use their wool, finally mine that iron that's just up the road, and see what kind of wheeling and dealing I can do with other royal figureheads.

Fabledom es un juego de construcción de ciudades estilo era medieval con mucho encanto. Hay que hacer crecer nuestra civilización para crear un reino y competir contra otros gobernantes. 



[b]Jugabilidad:[/b]
En el modo principal crearemos un mundo aleatorio donde tendremos que empezar a construir el hogar de los fablings.
Hay un modo creativo para hacer la ciudad como te plazca pero no le encuentro mucho interés, debería haber más edificios y muchas más construcciones decorativas.
Al ser un juego con acceso anticipado le falta mucho contenido y pulir algunas cosas. En mi humilde opinión, tras haber jugado varias horas, hay cosas que se podrían mejorar o arreglar. Las granjas sólo tienen 2 tipos de cultivos y no hay muchos objetos con los que fabricar otras cosas. A falta de añadir más edificios y con más funciones, estaría bien poder mejorar los construcciones o subirlas de nivel. Hay un héroe que de poco sirve, espero que implementen algún sistema de tropas o batallas contra otros reinos.  Por el momento el juego está muy verde pero tiene mucho potencial.

[b]Gráficos:[/b]
El entorno, las construcciones y los personajes están bien detallados, de asepecto simpático. Algunas texturas se ven muy borrosas de cerca. Por ahora le falta mucha optimización ya que es injugable en 4K (comparado con otros juegos con gráficos más punteros).

[b]Música:[/b]
Poco que decir. Los sonidos ambientales son agradables pero carece de una banda sonora interesante. Tiene un tema principal que es sencillo y relajante pero al final se vuelve repetitivo. También hay una canción de "halloween" que es divertida pero sólo suena cuando viene la bruja.


[hr][/hr]

En resumen, se trata de un juego entretenido y simpático que engancha. Se hace corto por la falta de contenido actual.

Content:

The first thing I liked about this game (aside from what I consider a clever name) is the art style.  This rich and beautiful art style that carries through all annual seasons and the detailed animations of working, building, waiting...its fun to just watch what you've built run for awhile every so often.

So let's talk about gameplay.  Like many city builders, you know you're going to need resources, housing, farming, etc...and this is all present in Fabledom, but you also must maintain relationships with other kingdoms. Another QOL would be I'd like to know if someone left or died.  I've seen my kingdom go from a max population to missing several citizens with no word to me that they're gone or why.  But hey, its Early Access.  All of this is to be expected.

Even for early access, this is pretty bare-bones for a city builder. There's not much more content outside what you see in the demo.

It is very cute though, with stylistic decisions I can get behind. I also like how they're making some of the structures less static than just placing squares and rectangles. They do need to extend this to more buildings than just housing and stockpiles though.

The biggest problem right now is that the "fable" part of the name is fairly cosmetic at this point. We are dealing with pigs with wings, there's a princess, and a talking tree somewhere on the map. Otherwise, it's just a regular city builder like you've played before. I've built the well for my houses in so many games. I've built the tavern to make my people happy countless times before. I've built the wheat farms for my windmills for my bakeries every year since playing Settlers II back on windows 98. Let me build and set up actual fable stuff. What about needing to build mushroom huts for gnome citizens, and then I can employ them to spin straw into gold? Or trying to host a coven of wicked witches but trying to put together a sufficiently spooky swamp in time?

Ultimately, this game has potential, but in the same way that a lump of rainbow playdoh has potential. It's kind of nothing right now except, appropriately, castles in the sky.

Impressive for such an incredibly small team. Cute, relaxing, though sometimes perplexing game at this stage. Lacks content, but it's clearly in the works. Balancing resources, people, money, and employment can be a challenge at times. 

I thought peasants would leave if they were homeless for too long since that's what the writing implied, but they just straight up starved to death without a home and dropped dead at the 'plaza.' So I unintentionally euthanized a third of my people when trying to replace peasants with common folk from lack of space. Then my common folk also began starving too- I'm wondering if "They're more demanding" means they consume more food? I got confused there.

Anyhow, after mass murdering dozens of people I made a new save and it's going great...

Coal makers feel highly inefficient with little employment, slow production, low desirability, and high upkeep after so many of them- only for the game to not even react if my people don't have coal to heat their homes in the winter. So I opted to just let them freeze since it's easy to ignore with no consequence. Coal makers are definitely my least favorite building in the game.

I hope the next neighboring ruler is a guy who looks... a touch more handsome than Giovanni... his character design is creative, funny, and unique- but I'm -not- that desperate. Oh dear.

I'd love a preview of what royalty/nobility points could unlock for me in the future. For now, I didn't care too much- though the pop up quests not having an option to decline without penalty (especially early on in the game) stressed me out. It felt like time was rolling the dice as to whether I was punished or punished less harshly, especially when struggling with money and food already. Hell, an option to turn those off for a more relaxing experience would be great too. It reminded me of sim city's random destruction events.

My least important peeve was the cake-like fog around the border edge of the map. Kinda kills my immersion when I view a map and the visual horizon from my camera doesn't match up, but I also have no idea how this could be fixed and I can see why the developers picked such a solution for now at least.

This game is cute and fun though, I'd probably play it again alongside Dorfromantik whenever I want something less intense than the usual.

It's early. Give the devs a chance. It is early access and you can tell a bit. Yet it is still the game I've spent the most time on lately (other than Dredge).

Summary: This is what the original Serf City / The Settlers franchise should have become.

Initial Thoughts:
* CUTE AS CRAP! It's fun, challenging, and cozy at the same time. Unless 1/2 your people die from starvation while the granaries are full. I just love how it looks.
* While a lot of content hasn't been released yet, I still spent SEVEN HOURS playing it the first time. Wow. Didn't even realize it. I was so engaged.
* It's easy to learn and play. Yet as the mid-game starts really happening it can be challenging not having some of the future building.
* Once you hit a good spot (a few hours in) you can let it "ant farm" and run on its own and just see what happens. I love that. Will probably stream that happening.
* Mechanics are similar to other games in the genre, yet seem to really flow much better than others games I've played recently.
* Some events, like The W---- (don't want to spoil anything), just seem super random and nothing you can do about it. I get having random events, but I hope long term that mean more or make more sense than just to cripple you for a time.
* I LOVE the simplicity and actual functionality of the Overview Menu. I do so much in there when my area gets big and has lots of Fablings. Other games have either too little or too much information. I don't want to play Excel. This game really does it nicely.

Little Annoyances (There are a few annoying things I'd love to see the devs adjust. And I did send feedback on these. Keep in mind this is early access... just some ideas.):
* The blue road placement icons look exactly like their water indicator. For HOURS I thought that's what they were. Please make them distinctive.
* I'd love to see the road placement indicators AFTER buildings are built too. Like when you click on them. It can help with planning and adjusting as your village evolves.
* Fablings can go up hills, but you can't put roads on hills. Seems odd. Would like that to change.
* Hoping that in the future they can get water from other sources than wells (rivers, springs).
* The UI is big. I'd love being able to adjust the UI elements (like the tool bars and such) as other games in the genre let you. And option to hide it for recording (I LOVE just watching the Fablings). I have an ultra-wide giant monitor and it is still super annoying in the long game.
* A few times zoom got stuck for me. I'd zoom out and it would just zoom all the way in. I'd have to restart it to get it to stop.

Overall, this game is great already. I just can't wait to see what it is a year from now. I'm already addicted and am excited to see where the dev team and designers are going to take it.

[code] Puedes seguir a nuestro [b]mentor[/b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6867212/] aquí [/url]para más análisis. [/code]

[h1]Fabledom[7][/h1]

El mundo de los videojuegos crece sin parar, está vez toca hablar de Fabledom, el nuevo título del debutante estudio Grenaa Games, formado únicamente por dos desarrolladores y editado por Dear Villagers, editora conocida por títulos como [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/S3NSEI-Analisis/recommended/1419160?snr=1_5_9__402] Souldiers[/url] o [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/nyper01/recommended/970830/]The dungeon of Naheulbeuk.[/url]  entre otros. 

[code]Fabledom no es otro city building de la lista, el título logra innovar en algunos aspectos, como la inclusión de un ambiente muy cozy. Aunque hay que decir que [b]ha sido lanzado en acceso anticipado - EA-[/b] y este análisis está basado en dicha versión por lo que puede que varíe próximamente.[/code] 

[h1]¡Erase una vez… un reino![/h1] 

 Fabledom arranca como si un cuento de hadas se tratara, gran parte de este encanto lo encontramos gracias a un narrador omnisciente que nos acompañará desde el comienzo de nuestra aventura como principe/princesa de un idílico reino en construcción. Por ello lo primero será seleccionar género y gustos, podemos elegir la carne, el pescado o incluso ambos. Tras esta pequeña selección comenzaremos nuestra aventura en nuestro reino,  pudiendo elegir entre 8 ubicaciones donde podremos ver la fertilidad de las tierras o incluso el tamaño máximo del reino. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2963151217

 Además decir que hay dos formas de jugar: 

[b]Modo estándar[/b]: donde debemos progresar haciendo crecer nuestro reino - el clásico sistema de eras que encontramos vigentes en muchos títulos como el querido Sid Meiers Civilizations. 

[b]Modo Creativo[/b]: donde tendremos todo desbloqueado desde el primer momento para dar pie a nuestra imaginación.

[h1]¡Nuestro cometido es la ley![/h1]

Como monarca de nuestro reino, deberemos ir construyendo el reino a nuestro antojo, que decir que no sepamos de un city building/colony sim. Debemos coger a nuestro aldeanos y darles oficios para hacer crecer nuestra pequeña comunidad. Comenzaremos con un set de edificios y profesiones muy limitados.

Lo más importante será darle cobijo a todo aquel que quiera unirse a nuestro querido reino, por ello todo habitante debe tener casa y un oficio con el que progresar. Desde el principio el avance es lento, podemos crear granjas de cultivos, una serrería para crear tablones o una cantera para coger roca. Todo edificio necesita alguien que lo administre. Hasta el almacén. Me ha gustado mucho que hayan decidido añadir que los almacenes sean customizables, pudiendo elegir desde un primer momento los materiales a almacenar en dicho lugar. Lo mismo ocurre con los molinos donde se irán almacenando alimentos. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2963172991

El videojuego, no trata de ser un colony sim complejo. No aceptar nuevos miembros no nos penalizará en exceso, de hecho nuestra moral no bajará por ello. Aunque esto tiene un problema nuestro objetivo es hacer crecer nuestra pequeña aldea y convertirla en un gran reino - Acoger a todo quisqui -. Desde un inicio nuestra expansión estará bloqueada, por suerte, nuestros aldeanos religiosamente pagan su diezmo y generan ganancias para nuestro reino. Con estas podremos ir agrandando nuestro territorio. El coste siempre va creciendo a medida que avancemos y entre otras cosas podemos encontrar ruinas de antiguos asentamientos, aquí es donde han decidido innovar ya que una función importante de Fabledom la encontramos en el cuartel de héroes, estos tendrán personalización y podrán guerrear, espiar y visitar ruinas, donde generalmente encontramos decoraciones para nuestro reino. Digo podrán porque a pesar de ser una mecánica fundamental ahora mismo no está implementada y únicamente sirven para visitar ruínas, quedando bastante limitados a día de hoy. 

Fabledom trata de ser la historia de príncipe enamorado, por lo que en ocasiones encontraremos eventos de otros monarcas que quieren hacer tratos con nosotros, otra función importante es la posibilidad de cortejar, Agnes por ejemplo, la princesa de la cosecha, nos pedirá trigo a modo de pagaré. Cortejar ahora mismo ocurre como con los héroes y solo nos dará nuevas decoraciones, Cada principe/sa pide algo diferente. 

[h1]Apartado técnico[/h1]

La interfaz de Fabledom es simple e intuitiva, un botón para avanzar el tiempo hasta x2 y un sistema de clima que va bastante bien. Superar el invierno no será tarea difícil, pero aun así deberemos guardar algo de alimentos, pues nuestras granjas no generarán. El título también cuenta con un sistema de gestión sencillo que nos permitirá ver si tenemos algún fabling sin empleo. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2963172495

En cuanto al apartado audiovisual, encontramos un estilo artístico muy colorido con curiosas animaciones, podremos seguir a nuestros fablins además con una vista en 3 persona que los seguirá durante su rutina. Aunque este aspecto está poco pulido, es interesante observar cómo trabajan o simplemente pasan su rato libre. Me ha recordado muchísimo a Overcooked en el estilo artístico. 

Sonoramente que decir, el título decide alardear de una buena melodía ambiental que nos acompañará pero nos permitirá centrarnos de lleno en la gestión de nuestro reino. 

[h1]¡Colorín Colorado, este cuento…![/h1]

En definitiva, Fabledom se trata de un buen city building/ colony sim descafeinado, su agradable aspecto artístico, hace que sea un título para todos los públicos, muy recomendable. Aunque a pesar de ser un juego en acceso anticipado, hay algo que he echado en falta desde un primer momento, y ha sido la inclusión de logros. Por suerte el título ha llegado subtitulado a nuestro idioma entre otros, y va a estar cargado de contenido. Por lo que os aconsejo echar un ojo a su como [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2963787420&fileuploadsuccess=1] roadmap[/url] para ver lo que nos aguarda. 

[h1]🥈​​​Nota: 7/10[/h1]

136780367.review:
After playing the game more in depth I am giving a more detailed review of the game. I will keep it as short and easy to follow as possible

Summary
In short, this game is in very early development and is still missing some important pieces in the early game, and has basically no mid or late game yet. If you are looking for experiencing a fulfillling story/charming and developed building experience, the game is not there yet. The designers are working fast and transparently, so I'd take a look in a few months and see if there is enough content for you then (I'd say after the 2nd roadmap patch it would be playable enough to enjoy more deeply). As for what the game offers now is an introduction and baseline to play around with and is engaging enough to keep me testing it.

Pros

- Charming theme with a lot of character and style. There is potential to be fleshed out more in a way a fable-esque game should be
- The main foundations of the game in terms of resources and UI are clean and easily understandable. As the game develops, I am hoping for more unique or rare/useful items with the intriguing heroes system.
- There is a charming story and larger map you can interact with that I am hoping to speak on more as the game develops. Promise of trade, war and love with neighboring kingdoms is a very exciting concept to me in this game.
- Haven't seen any game breaking bugs or issues which is a huge plus for a game so early in development

Cons

- While there are fantasy elements, its missing the trolls, goblins, fairies and other fable creatures that would really elevate the game. I am expecting to see these creature included after the next patch as enemies to fight.
- There are some vital management views and options that are missing. Adding in additional overlays to see happiness and routes would be beneficial. Also adding negative/positive seasonal or yearly forecast yields would be immensely beneficial for planning the city or a district.
- Not a lot story or interactions happening for a game based on stories. While it is early development, I'd love to see cutscenes of important benchmarks with the main story, and more importantly, interactions of fablings in the city. Seeing them attend street theatre, go to the inn, slack off at work, or interact with other fablings, buildings, and environments would be a huge boon to the theme of the game

Critiques/Feedback

While I listed out some of the more pressing feedback in the cons above, there are some other pieces that could use a touch  mentioned below.

- Give Fablings experience in their set jobs, the longer they work the same job the better they are
- Have different aged fablings, maybe even kids in the city who can't work or take up household spaces but hang around the city or at home to give more life to a city.
- Give buildings upgrades, give storage workers a wagon to move more resources around the city faster. As the main source of resource transportation at the moment, they seem a bit slow


In conclusion the game looks great and feels great. I am giving a positive review as the game development is good and the designers are very active. I am hoping as the game reaches completion I can come back and remove all my cons! Hoping this game goes far.

Fabledom is absolutely loaded with charm and an equal amount of potential. If you're interested in a relatively laid-back city-builder, this one's for you. My Pros and Cons:

Pros:
- Easy to get into and maintain
- Relaxing environment
- Cheap!
- Minimal/No bugs, certainly not gamebreaking ones
- Easy mechanics
- Mechanics generally work as intended

Cons:
- No ability to direct Fablings (like in Keflings) so sometimes it seems like they don't listen to prioritized builds
- Minimal content (Obviously, being early access, this makes sense, but I feel I've seen mostly everything to see with around 6 hours played)
- Repetitive music (Like 2 or 3 tracks)
- Curse mechanic, which I'm not entirely sure is avoidable, that can happen at the worst times, frequently (Doubles food drain)

There is a ton of potential to be tapped here. If I had to rate it right now, I'd give it a 7/10. Its very fun for what it is, but I feel for the most part that the money I put into it is stock for the future (which is good, because its a cheap entry point). There's enough here to give you some enjoyment for a day, and I recommend it, but don't expect to be bogged down for days on end just yet.

There is nothing heinous about this game. Is a well-built city builder medieval game with a cute art style. The reason I am leaving a negative review is because the game brings nothing new to the table. I really enjoyed playing the demo of Fabledom, so I instantly purchased the early access version when it got released.

It has to be said: I love the aesthetics of the game, and the overall gameplay mechanics. It is a very cozy, cute city builder with a little romance. The soundtrack is great, too.

Gameplay-wise: The core mechanics are easy to understand, and the city building is fun. The game certainly has a learning curve regarding how to strategically set up storage etc. I will place a bunch of buildings differently in my next playthrough.

However, since the game is in early access, a bunch of features aren't available yet. After finishing the "early game" and moving on into the town era, the pacing felt very off in my opinion. The hero character also currently feels fairly arbitrary. Obviously the game has just been released and isn't fully developed, so I hope some balancing changes will be  made. (I was just watching youtube while waiting to accumulate more money, having built lots of homesteads and having neither the territory nor the money to build town housing.) In addition to balancing, a feature I would enjoy is to control my supply of wood and stone versus what gets turned into other building materials. I really dislike not having any stone because it all got used up... This being said, this is all criticism on a very high level.

Overall, this Fabledom is a wonderful game. With some balancing changes and additional gameplay, it has great potential, and really hits the spot for me, which not a lot of citybuilders do. Good luck and much love to the devs for creating this gem.

I often never leave a review, and reserve it only for such an occasion. This game is special. And a dev specifically asked for this as a favor in their Discord, so, ya' gotta do it!

Just to make it easy - great music, fun city builder, a great voice actor/narrator, and a wonderful combination of silly/cartoony and realistic as an art style. And at $15 or $20? Nah, go for it! Give it a try. 

A bit more in-depth - this game is made by a two-man dev team. Which is as mind-blowing as learning Manor Lords is a one-man dev team. With Fabledom, you feel the love they put into their project. There's a story here that will be fleshed out along with the game's development - delivered by game mechanics and a fantastic, sort of nostalgic narrator. The art style is very well crafted, allowing an indie team to seem like they're competing with PIXAR. The game has hints of Banished, Manor Lords, and in some sense, ANNO 1800. The game is calm and easy-going. I saw one comment that was pretty on point - Fabledom feels like how the new Settlers game should have felt.

And my top compliment - this game allows for travelling the map, and does a great mix of cute, cartoony city-building, with later-on added elements of combat. You can eventually build a castle and the surrounding walls, with both footmen and archers. 

Overall, support the game, support their art. Give it a try!

To note though - two negatives. One, as with most city-builders, the game is too easy. Again with other city builders, I doubt there's an End screen. The focus is of course actually building, designing, and decorating a city. But it needs far greater challenges and true game-ending events, if the player isn't focused or strategic. This might be mitigated slightly when combat is introduced soon.

Two - so far, nothing is really new here. You can tell there's love from the devs from this project. It feels like a game from the 90's or early 2000's when devs really, really were trying. I'm reminded of Halo...... But anyway, the game's great and it's fun to play. Buuut, aside from the story line, there's nothing really new here. Hoping to see what happens later on though!
